claim: In the US, anyone can carry a gun legally.

supporting.text: The Second Amendment of the US Constitution protects the right of individuals to keep and bear arms.

attacks.text: The Second Amendment of the US Constitution protects the right of individuals to keep and bear arms.
The Second Amendment is subject to interpretation and regulation, such as background checks and restrictions on certain types of firearms.
Legal precedents like District of Columbia v. Heller affirm an individual's right to bear arms, but also allow for reasonable regulations.
Some states and localities have strict gun control laws that effectively limit who can legally carry a gun.
Federal law preempts some state restrictions, ensuring a baseline right to bear arms across the country.
Certain individuals, such as convicted felons or those with mental health issues, are legally prohibited from carrying guns.
These prohibitions are exceptions to the general rule and do not negate the broad constitutional right to bear arms.

supporting.text: Federal and state laws impose restrictions on gun ownership, such as background checks and prohibitions for certain individuals like convicted felons.

attacks.text: Federal and state laws impose restrictions on gun ownership, such as background checks and prohibitions for certain individuals like convicted felons.
Some states have very permissive gun laws, allowing open or concealed carry without a permit.
Even in permissive states, federal background checks still apply, and certain individuals remain prohibited from owning guns.
The Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, implying broad legal access to guns.
Courts have ruled that the Second Amendment is not unlimited and can be restricted for public safety.

supporting.text: Some states require permits or licenses to carry concealed firearms, which are not automatically granted to all individuals.

attacks.text: Some states require permits or licenses to carry concealed firearms, which are not automatically granted to all individuals.
The Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, and many states have constitutional carry laws allowing gun carry without permits.
Even in constitutional carry states, private property owners and certain public spaces can still prohibit firearms, restricting the practical ability to carry guns freely.
Federal law prohibits certain individuals, such as felons and those with mental health issues, from owning or carrying firearms, regardless of state laws.

supporting.text: Federal law prohibits certain categories of people, such as those with domestic violence convictions or mental health adjudications, from legally possessing firearms.

attacks.text: Federal law prohibits certain categories of people, such as those with domestic violence convictions or mental health adjudications, from legally possessing firearms.
Many states have loopholes or weak enforcement mechanisms that allow prohibited individuals to obtain firearms illegally.
Federal background checks (NICS) are mandatory for all firearm purchases from licensed dealers, significantly reducing illegal access.
Private sales and gun shows often bypass background checks, enabling prohibited persons to acquire firearms easily.
Several states have enacted universal background check laws to close the private sale loophole.

supporting.text: Open carry laws vary by state, with some states allowing it without a permit and others restricting or banning it entirely.

attacks.text: Open carry laws vary by state, with some states allowing it without a permit and others restricting or banning it entirely.
Federal law still allows individuals to purchase and own firearms, even if open carry is restricted in certain states.
Federal law does not override state laws on open carry, meaning state restrictions still effectively limit who can carry a gun in public.
Even in states with restrictions, concealed carry permits are often available, allowing legal gun carrying under certain conditions.
Concealed carry permits require background checks, training, and fees, which are barriers preventing 'anyone' from carrying a gun.

supporting.text: The US Supreme Court has ruled that the Second Amendment does not guarantee an unlimited right to carry any type of firearm in any manner.

attacks.text: The US Supreme Court has ruled that the Second Amendment does not guarantee an unlimited right to carry any type of firearm in any manner.
Many states have 'shall-issue' or 'constitutional carry' laws that allow individuals to carry firearms without significant restrictions.
Even in 'shall-issue' states, background checks and other regulations are often required, limiting the claim that 'anyone' can carry a gun.
Federal law prohibits certain individuals, such as convicted felons or those with domestic violence restraining orders, from carrying firearms.
Enforcement of these federal prohibitions is inconsistent, and many individuals who are legally barred from carrying firearms still do so.
